Award.AwardTitle: Brassinosteroid-auxin synergism to dissect hormone response pathways in Arabidopsis
Award.AbstractNarration: A major unanswered question in developmental biology is how the final size of an animal or plant is determined. This study explores the roles of hormones in regulating organ size and stature in plants. Recent studies in the P.I.'s laboratory indicate that the plant hormones auxin and brassinosteroids (BRs) act in close proximity to regulate seedling growth. Using genetics, genomics, and physiological analyses, it was shown that the auxin and BR pathways are interconnected and this integration is likely to occur at the level of gene expression. This project will continue to explore the underlying molecular mechanism of this BR/auxin synergism and seek to identify new factors involved in growth regulation by BRs and auxin. These experiments will address the mechanism by which these hormones interact to regulate such diverse responses as changes in gene expression, cell expansion and division, and tissue differentiation. The long-term objective is to completely understand the signaling networks that regulate plant development in response to an ever-changing environment, and to relate this to strategies used in other organisms. An anticipated broader impact is a continuing commitment to post-graduate, graduate, and undergraduate education, as well as exposure of high school students to a research laboratory setting. Also, the computational analyses to be carried out allow access to publicly available datasets that are of general use to the molecular biology community, and we have made the information available through several recently implemented websites. Consequently, the analytical methods and the information generated by their implementation may be a valuable community resource.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Steroid hormones are essential for growth, development, and homeostasis of animals, insects, and plants (Figure 1). In plants, one class of polyhydroxylated steroids, called brassinosteroids (BRs), has wide distribution throughout the plant kingdom and unique growth promoting activities (Figure 1).  Previously, we identified the membrane-localized receptor, BRI1, as well as many of its downstream signaling components. BRI1 is a Toll-like receptor kinase comprised of a large extracellular ligand-binding domain containing 25 leucine-rich repeats, a trans-membrane segment and a cytoplasmic kinase domain. We proposed that the extracellular domain of BRI1 binds the steroid hormone, which then induces a conformational change in the receptor that in turn leads to autophosphorylation of the cytoplasmic kinase domain and the dissociation of the kinase inhibitor protein BKI1.This increases the affinity of BRI1 for its co-receptor, BAK1, a receptor kinase with 5 LRRs. Extensive cross-phosphorylation events activates the receptor/co-receptor complex (Figure 2). A 3-dimensional structure for BRI1 bound to brassinosteroid, not only explains how this receptor has specificity for brassinostoids, but it also explains why similar steroids from insects and humans do not bind to BRI1 (Figure 3).  

A detailed map of hormone response pathways is essential for dissecting complex processes, such as how a plant makes an informed decision to grow or not.  A second major objective of this grant was to dissect the mechanisms of brassinosteroid interactions with another plant growth promoting hormone, auxin. Brassinosteroids and auxin affect many of the same genes that regulate growth. We examined whether they regulate these genes through the same or independent pathways, and identified a point of crosstalk between BRI1 and auxin signaling through the GSK3-like kinase, BIN2.  

A two-year extension of the original grant was awarded in 2011. This allowed us to follow up on an observation that BAK1 is a shared component between the brassinosteroid and innate immunity signaling pathway activated by bacterial flagellin. Our studies implicate a role for BAK1 in the pivotal trade-off between a plant's decision to outgrow a pathogen or to fight it.   

Together, our studies have elucidated the mechanism of action of brassinosteroid binding and signaling to BRI1 to 2.8 angstroms resolution.  This information was then used to further our understanding of how plants optimize their growth rates for particular environments,
